ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Interesting aspects of the Japanese culture and language, skills in public speaking.

I was able to learn more vocabulary and shore up some of my Japanese grammar by taking this course. However, by this level, improving significantly in Japanese can only really be made by studying abroad.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I really liked it, maybe would appreciate more modern or relevant readings.

A strength of this class is that it is very small and Yamaguchi-Sensei is extremely engaging and exciting to talk to. A weakness is that many different people are at many different levels, which can be difficult. Some are very skilled in Kanji but not in oral, and vice versa.

The textbook for this course is appropriately challenging, making it a good bridge between intermediate and advanced Japanese. The presentations also seemed like a good way to gauge learning progress over the course of the semester. Meeting with the TF was the best part of this course because it gave me real hands-on practice with spoken Japanese!

One downside to this course is that it seems unnecessarily time consuming at times. The vocab quizzes for instance require multiple hours of studying for a 10-minute quiz, and then the vocab words are forgotten easily as they never come up in class again. A lot of the time, it felt like learning vocab and kanji just to be able to do the homework and then most of class time is spent going over homework answers instead of practicing conversational skills or really going into depth on grammar points.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes; the language is very important and opens up a new world
Yes, great professor, very effective in improving my Japanese
Yes, but if they don't have time for the class, I would recommend doing a study abroad experience in Japan instead.
